WILLIAM MCCLEAN

University, Hospital

Of Johns Hopkins

William McClean was elected to
the presidency of the Student Council for 1934-1935 over Roland Merson in the final elections held yesterday in Latrobe Hall from 1 p. m.
to 3 p. m.
Edward Sadtler, president of the
Council for the year 1933-1934, and
Theodore Stern supervised the election of the two candidates surviving the primaries, in which T. Bayard Williams, Arthur Denues, Cliff
Siverd, Stanley Blumberg and Bob
McKericher were eliminated.
Meade Johnson, president of this
year's Sophomore Class, and David
Levy were elected junior representatives to next year's Council,
while Charles VanDusen was selected to represent next year's
Sophomore Class.

Friday, May 18, 1934.

Matters Of Moment
The past three days brought forth so much news
of note that we feel justified in passing brief editorial
comment upon each item. Reading from top to bottom:
CAGE FUND EXTENSION—
As was to be expected, one week proved insufficient time for the thorough completion of such a
campaign. But what really irks is the fact that the
students are allowing the faculty to take the play right
out of their hands.
One hundred and nine undergraduate contributors! One-seventh of the entire group! Surely more
than this comparative handful are/interested in seeing
a cage erected by next year for their use. If we
hadn't seen the list of contributors with our own eyes,
we would have been inclined to suspect that Ed Sadtler was repaying us by such a mocking jest for some
of the friendly digs which we have let go in his
direction this spring. As it is, we still refuse to
believe that every student's name will not be on the
dotted line by next Tuesday.
Remember that slogan: Not "Give all", but "All
give."
McCLEAN GAINS COUNCIL PRESIDENCY—
One of the most evenly contested finals in the history of Student Council elections, with both men possessing certain salient attributes and yet differing
in many respects. McClean should certainly be one
well-informed and occupied campus figure next year,
what with his other offices as captain of the football
team and member of the athletic committee. We
hereby pledge him the support of the NEWS-LETTER
from scratch.
Congratulations are also due Dave Levy and
Meade Johnson, but for quite a different reason.
Their automatic election on the basis of a complete
absence of further nominees compels us to reach the
following alternate conclusion concerning the present
Sophomore Class: Either the members as a unit were
convinced that Levy and Johnson were by far the best
qualified and equipped men for the positions (which,
in spite of their excellent records heretofore, we
do not consider altogether likely) ; or the class refused to take any interest whatever in its choice of
representatives to the Council. We really don't see
how it can find much cause for self congratulations
in having established such a precedent.
Be that as it may, the two successful candidates,
as well as Charles Van Dusen of the frosh, can be
expected to turn in a satisfactory job on the Council
next year, if their evident eagerness to represent their
respective classes is to be taken as a criterion.

Freshman Holds
Defeat Jays Promising

In Last Meet Defense On Varsity Ten
Widmyer Leads Maryland To
Victory With First Places
In The 100, 220 Dashes

Final Score 86-39
Holtzman Triumphs In TwoMile, Breaking Dual Meet
Record In Time Of 9:58.8
Capturing only four of the fourteen events, the Johns Hopkins
track team succumbed to a strong
Maryland aggregation last Wednesday at Homewood, losing by the
score of 86 1-3 to 39 2-3.
The Terps, led by the flashy Earl
Widmyer, who was victorious in
two events, built up a commanding
lead in the track events, winning
all but one of the running contests.
This race, the two-mile event, was
won by Paul Holtzman of the Jays
in the time of 9:58.8. Holtzman
came from behind in the last lap
to pass two Colloge Park contestants and break the meet record for
his specialty.
King Absent

The Black and Blue was handicapped by the absence of Jack King,
who was unable to compete on Wednesday. In the absence of King,
Emmert and Sholtes made a valiant
attempt to triumph in the mile, but
both runners were nosed out by
Beall of Maryland. Beall won in
the time of 4:41, a performance
which King has bettered in the past.
Surprisingly enough, the Jays
showed up best in the field events,
in which they have been rather weak
throughout the season. In the
weight contests particularly, the
Black and Blue shook its old nemesis when it succeeded in triumphing in the discus and shot-put. In
the former event, Hopkins obtained
first and second when Chancellor
and Moravek both were able to top
the throws of Coulehan, the Terps'
best performore. Chancellor won
with a heave of 118 feet 10 inches.
Moravek

Don Naylor, brilliant Jay stick
defense man, should undoubtedly
prove to be one of Coach Van Orman's most valuable cogs in the
building of future Hopkins lacrosse
machines. A freshman now, Don
is playing his first year of varsity
lacrosse for the Hopkins.
As many other Jay lacrossemen,
Naylor acquired his early stick
training in one of Baltiinore's secHe attended
ondary schools.
Friends before coming to the Hopkins, where he not only participated
in lacrosse but also in basketball
and in football.
Commenting upon his first desires to play lacrosse, Naylor stated
that it had always been his intent
to follow in his cousin Don Kelly's
footsteps.
Naylor proved his worth in the
Jay-Johnny game by repeatedly
stopping the dangerous. advances of
Smith, who is the leading individual
high. scorer.
With St. John's safely tucked
away, says Naylor, Hopkins is a
sure bet over Maryland, but account
should be taken of preceding scores
which show us that the Jays always
played at their worst against Maryland and their best against St.
John's. A victory over the Terps
will mean the third successive championship for Hopkins.

Concluding their season, the Jay
netmen will encounter Lehigh this
afternoon at Homewood. Little is
known as to the, relative strength of
the Bethlehem team, as it has met
none of Hopkins' previous opponents.
This match will be the last for

other player, and his loss will be
hard to replace.

Headed by Captain Brooke, the
Jays will send a formidable group
in the Baltimore City Tennis Championship, which will start Monday
at the Suburban Club.
Ladensky, Palitz, Kramer, and
Hartman have entered, and may be

have been members of the team for
the past four years, have been one
of the • best doubles combinations
ever at Hopkins. Only North
Carolina's first doubles team boasts
a victory over this pair.

Council for the year 1933-1934, and

McKericher were eliminated.

year's Sophomore Class, and David
Levy were elected junior representatives to next year's Council,
while Charles VanDusen was selected to represent next year's
Sophomore Class.

Friday, May 18, 1934.

Matters Of Moment
The past three days brought forth so much news
of note that we feel justified in passing brief editorial
comment upon each item. Reading from top to bottom:
CAGE FUND EXTENSION—
As was to be expected, one week proved insufficient time for the thorough completion of such a
campaign. But what really irks is the fact that the
students are allowing the faculty to take the play right
out of their hands.
One hundred and nine undergraduate contributors! One-seventh of the entire group! Surely more
than this comparative handful are/interested in seeing
a cage erected by next year for their use. If we
hadn't seen the list of contributors with our own eyes,
we would have been inclined to suspect that Ed Sadtler was repaying us by such a mocking jest for some
of the friendly digs which we have let go in his
direction this spring. As it is, we still refuse to
believe that every student's name will not be on the
dotted line by next Tuesday.
Remember that slogan: Not "Give all", but "All
give."
McCLEAN GAINS COUNCIL PRESIDENCY—
One of the most evenly contested finals in the history of Student Council elections, with both men possessing certain salient attributes and yet differing
in many respects. McClean should certainly be one
well-informed and occupied campus figure next year,
what with his other offices as captain of the football
team and member of the athletic committee. We
hereby pledge him the support of the NEWS-LETTER
from scratch.
Congratulations are also due Dave Levy and
Meade Johnson, but for quite a different reason.
Their automatic election on the basis of a complete
absence of further nominees compels us to reach the
following alternate conclusion concerning the present
Sophomore Class: Either the members as a unit were
convinced that Levy and Johnson were by far the best
qualified and equipped men for the positions (which,
in spite of their excellent records heretofore, we
do not consider altogether likely) ; or the class refused to take any interest whatever in its choice of
representatives to the Council. We really don't see
how it can find much cause for self congratulations
in having established such a precedent.
Be that as it may, the two successful candidates,
as well as Charles Van Dusen of the frosh, can be
expected to turn in a satisfactory job on the Council
next year, if their evident eagerness to represent their
respective classes is to be taken as a criterion.

Terrapins NAYLOR NETMEN
Freshman Holds
Defeat Jays Promising
Down Position Of First
In Last Meet Defense On Varsity Ten
Widmyer Leads Maryland To
Victory With First Places
In The 100, 220 Dashes

Final Score 86-39
Holtzman Triumphs In TwoMile, Breaking Dual Meet
Record In Time Of 9:58.8
Capturing only four of the fourteen events, the Johns Hopkins
track team succumbed to a strong
Maryland aggregation last Wednesday at Homewood, losing by the
score of 86 1-3 to 39 2-3.
The Terps, led by the flashy Earl
Widmyer, who was victorious in
two events, built up a commanding
lead in the track events, winning
all but one of the running contests.
This race, the two-mile event, was
won by Paul Holtzman of the Jays
in the time of 9:58.8. Holtzman
came from behind in the last lap
to pass two Colloge Park contestants and break the meet record for
his specialty.
King Absent

The Black and Blue was handicapped by the absence of Jack King,
who was unable to compete on Wednesday. In the absence of King,
Emmert and Sholtes made a valiant
attempt to triumph in the mile, but
both runners were nosed out by
Beall of Maryland. Beall won in
the time of 4:41, a performance
which King has bettered in the past.
Surprisingly enough, the Jays
showed up best in the field events,
in which they have been rather weak
throughout the season. In the
weight contests particularly, the
Black and Blue shook its old nemesis when it succeeded in triumphing in the discus and shot-put. In
the former event, Hopkins obtained
first and second when Chancellor
and Moravek both were able to top
the throws of Coulehan, the Terps'
best performore. Chancellor won
with a heave of 118 feet 10 inches.
Moravek

Don Naylor, brilliant Jay stick
defense man, should undoubtedly
prove to be one of Coach Van Orman's most valuable cogs in the
building of future Hopkins lacrosse
machines. A freshman now, Don
is playing his first year of varsity
lacrosse for the Hopkins.
As many other Jay lacrossemen,
Naylor acquired his early stick
training in one of Baltiinore's secHe attended
ondary schools.
Friends before coming to the Hopkins, where he not only participated
in lacrosse but also in basketball
and in football.
Commenting upon his first desires to play lacrosse, Naylor stated
that it had always been his intent
to follow in his cousin Don Kelly's
footsteps.
Naylor proved his worth in the
Jay-Johnny game by repeatedly
stopping the dangerous. advances of
Smith, who is the leading individual
high. scorer.
With St. John's safely tucked
away, says Naylor, Hopkins is a
sure bet over Maryland, but account
should be taken of preceding scores
which show us that the Jays always
played at their worst against Maryland and their best against St.
John's. A victory over the Terps
will mean the third successive championship for Hopkins.

Concluding their season, the Jay
netmen will encounter Lehigh this
afternoon at Homewood. Little is
known as to the, relative strength of
the Bethlehem team, as it has met
none of Hopkins' previous opponents.

other player, and his loss will be
hard to replace.
